I work as a prison chaplain here in Victoria and I see that those prisoners who are in contact with their family, who have the ability for their family to visit them in prison are, in fact, far more manageable within the prison environment than people who are completely isolated from their families.

And then, you know, as the sentence proceeds and the person is preparing for release back in to the community—because they are still members of the community. As they are preparing for release back in to the community the prospects of some form of resettlement, effective resettlement, are heightened so much if the person is in contact with people who are close to them: their own family, their wife, their husband, their children.

That seems like commonsense. It clearly underpins the importance of this particular legislation. Australian citizens who return to Australia have a much greater capacity to rehabilitate into the community. If they are in close proximity to significant other people in their lives, they will have a more effective chance of becoming contributing members of the community.

There are obviously cost advantages to the proposal as well. Other speakers have spoken about the effect on consular services. There is some debate in the report of the House of Representatives committee about the competing levels of prisoners going out of Australia as distinct from those coming in. The balance of views seems to be that it is likely to favour Australia, perhaps marginally.

The other factor which I want to re‐emphasise is the advantage to the Australian community in terms of getting people rehabilitated as effective members of the community and the costs that are involved in the community with recidivism—that is, repeat offending.

It is well established internationally that, where prisoners are given effective opportunities to rehabilitate, to learn meaningful employment skills, where they can maintain their health— which they are going to be in a much better position to do in an Australian prison than overseas—the ultimate benefits to the Australian community in terms of avoiding the costs of repeat offences, in terms of health breakdowns, in terms of getting prisoners into employment and supporting their families, are going to be significantly greater if they are operating within an Australian environment.

Other members have spoken about Thai prisons. I visited a prison in Bangkok a few years ago. I can assure you that that is not an environment that is likely to produce rehabilitation for Australian offenders incarcerated there. They are, by and large, almost exclusively, people convicted of drug offences, but they are scarcely the Mr Bigs of the drug scene.

I think it would probably be true to describe most of the Australians I had the opportunity to meet in Bangkok prisons as `mules'—that is the colloquial expression. They are typically drug dependent people who have been caught trying to support their habit by carrying narcotics out of that jurisdiction. Their prospects of ever becoming effective citizens back in Australia are not going to be supported by their remaining for lengthy periods of time in the corrupt environment of Thai gaols.

There are a number of features of the advisory report by the House of Representatives committee that I wanted to comment on. One is to note that it is good to see Australia, through this legislation, assuming some responsibilities arising from war crimes tribunal matters in both the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda. This legislation gives effect in a number of ways to Australia's capacity to meet international obligations in those circumstances, and that is something that both sides of the House can applaud.

Other speakers have spoken about the national application of this legislation and the desirability of it, and we have heard that the Northern Territory apparently is continuing to indicate that it does not wish to participate. There is some reference in the committee's report to the possibility that Western Australia may have some difficulties. It was certainly canvassed in submissions to the committee, particularly from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Sidoti, who was quoted as saying:
. . . the bill should provide explicitly for extension to all Australian internal territories, either directly or by way of regulation, if the territories do not legislate.

The recommendation of the committee is against that particular approach. But it would seem to me that the Commonwealth ought not to totally forgo some considerable leverage on territories or states that do not come into this on a voluntary basis, simply because I think the overall advantages generally in Australia are somewhat diminished if particular jurisdictions, for whatever reason, decide to stay out. I think that it really is an area which it is sufficiently important to attempt very vigorously to get a national approach on, even if that involves some fairly heavy negotiation with the states. I am not sure, but I would suspect that my side of the parliament would ultimately fairly vigorously support that approach, if it became necessary.

Another important consideration that was dealt with in the standing committee's report was the question of eligibility of transfer under the legislation. I referred earlier to the James Savage matter in the United States. He was a young man of Aboriginal origin who was taken as a very young child from Australia and adopted by some people in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a US citizen, wasn't he?

—Yes, I think he became a US citizen. That raised some particular issues which were also addressed by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its submission to the parliamentary committee. The Attorney‐General's Department and the immigration department in their submissions to the committee came out very vigorously in opposition to making specific provisions for people of Aboriginal origin in the sorts of circumstances that Mr Savage found himself in. A Mr Meaney from the Attorney‐General's Department said:

BREAK.PARA: What we [would] have is a right for a class of persons—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders—who have been convicted of offences overseas to return to Australia but no general right of getting back into Australia under the Migration Act for, if you like, law abiding persons of the same extraction who might have been in the same class.

I think that point is reasonably well made. But I think the logical conclusion of it is not as the Attorney‐General's Department seems to be suggesting—that is, not taking steps to facilitate the capacity of people of Aboriginal extraction to return to Australia in the sorts of circumstances that Savage found himself in—but, rather, to create opportunities for non‐offending people in the same sort of category to also have some rights of return, given what we are increasingly learning about the terrible consequences of so much of the assimilation policy that was adopted in earlier decades towards Aboriginal children.

Clearly, a number of those children did leave the Australian jurisdiction. I would think the implication of this is not to put barriers in the way of the type of person that Savage is; but, rather, to look at the more general proposition of those who have not been convicted and look at some sort of restitution of rights. The committee does recommend that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) initiate some examination of the issues surrounding the eligibility of persons who have been removed from Australia as children to have a right of entry to Australia. That is welcome. I would join the committee in supporting that and would urge the minister to move on that particular matter very promptly.

The final matter in the committee's report that I wanted to comment on was the question of the Attorney‐General's discretion under a number of aspects of this legislation. The member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) and the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) have both referred to a particular area where it would seem desirable for the Attorney‐General to keep a discretion under review to ensure that injustices were not being done. Elizabeth Evatt, in a submission to the parliamentary committee, said the following:
I would like to think that all the discretions that will be exercised under the Act will be exercised in a manner compatible with our international human rights obligations . . .

I would like this committee to make a strong statement like that as a guiding principle to the way that the Act should be exercised. If it is in your report, it will be there for all time for whoever is exercising discretions and it will be there if any act of any government officer or Attorney‐General comes up for judicial review as a question of exercise legally. They will be able to look at that to see that it was the intention that we should at all times be compatible with human rights standards and not risk a violation by a transfer.

I wholeheartedly endorse those comments and believe that it would be very helpful, at the close of the second reading debate, if the Attorney‐General was able to give the committee the pleasure of his company to get some assurances from him in relation to the basis on which he would propose under this legislation to exercise his discretion.

It seems to me that one of the reasons, which the committee did not particularly address, that that discretion is important is that the circumstances in particular countries with which Australia might enter into treaty arrangements may change over time. One could look, for example, at Greece which was referred to as a place where there are a number of Australian citizens who are prisoners. Greece may well be a democracy now, but a few decades ago it was run by a military junta. Clearly, the sorts of circumstances that operate in particular countries change from time to time. We may well wish to look at the situation that exists in a country where the treaty obligations are incurred, by having the Attorney‐General of the day make it quite clear that his discretions in that respect will be influenced very strongly by the human rights position in particular countries.

I referred earlier to my visit to the prisons in the United States a number of years ago and to the very wide diversity of prison experiences there. They range from very progressive prisons, in the sense of prisons focused very much on getting high levels of rehabilitation so that rates of recidivism are reduced, right through to places which, as I described earlier, you would even hesitate to call electronic zoos—places that are quite brutalising and dehumanising for the prisoners in them.

Over time, even within a single country, I would think circumstances are going to change. That simply reinforces the importance of the Attorney‐General having a discretion in a range of areas here and reinforcing the basis of it. So I will conclude my remarks by urging the Attorney‐General to come to the Main Committee, if he is able to, and give some assurances. That would be extremely helpful in relation to laying the basis on which Australia will exercise its responsibilities under this legislation and the treaties that will arise as a result of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When I heard of the International Transfer of Prisoners Bill, I was one of those concerned that perhaps there would not be the benefits in the legislation that its proponents have, in fact, advanced. But I have been convinced that this legislation will be of benefit both to this country and to those overseas. Of course, the legislation, as has been pointed out by my colleagues, will allow Australians serving prison sentences overseas to be returned to Australia and will permit foreign nationals imprisoned in this country to return to their own countries to complete their sentences.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects to this particular legislation. Firstly, it covers general prisoner transfers. With respect to those general prisoner transfers, the transfer scheme is able to apply to all offences without exception. It covers persons who have been convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment or other deprivation of liberty and includes persons confined in connection with criminal conduct by reason of mental disorder and persons who have been released on parole.

As has been previously pointed out, these transfers will be consensual, requiring the consent of the person to be transferred, the relevant Australian government—Commonwealth and state/territory—and the other country. Conditions for transfer include imprisonment under a final order and for there to be at least six months of the sentence remaining to be served, unless the Attorney‐General determines that transfer for a shorter period is acceptable. Transfer conditions to Australia include the person being an Australian citizen or permitted to travel to, enter and remain in Australia indefinitely, pursuant to the Migration Act 1958, and having community ties with a state or territory.

When I first read that non‐citizens in certain circumstances would be able to return to Australia, I thought of citizens of countries like New Zealand whose non‐citizens, though nonAustralians, are still able to reside here. If New Zealand, for instance, does not enter into a similar scheme to that being entered into by Australia, it could be that New Zealanders languishing in Thai or South‐East Asian prisons might well want to come to Australia, which is closer to home. Our prisons are clearly very much more humane.

BREAK.PARA: I was pleased to see section 57, which points out that the Attorney‐General must not make any decision under this act affecting a prisoner who is not an Australian citizen without the consent of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. So, the concern that I had, and I believe the concern that would be widespread in the community, ultimately turned out not to be something to worry about.

I must say, though, that it is important to recognise that in 1997 Australia is a humanitarian country and that there will be humanitarian, economic and social advantages of an international transfer scheme for prisoners in which this country participates. Prior to my return to the federal parliament, I was for a period Chairman of the West Moreton Regional Community Corrections Board, which was the parole board covering prisons in Brisbane and, for a while, elsewhere. The two major prisons we covered were the Sir David Longland and Wacol correctional centres. At times we did have responsibility for the infamous Boggo Road Goal and the Borallon private prison, referred to by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) opposite.

With respect to correctional matters, it is always important to strike the appropriate balance between a penalty and rehabilitation. I think most people in the community would agree we need a balance. The difference that sometimes arises might be just on where that particular balance should be struck. But, when one looks at the prisons that the honourable member opposite has seen in some other parts of the world, the prisons that we know exist in certain parts of South‐East Asia, I suppose as Australians with a Western culture we have to ask whether those prison conditions are suitable for Australian prisoners. This legislation, to an extent, moves very much along the road towards encouraging a humanitarian approach to those Australian prisoners who are incarcerated overseas.

Some people could criticise this particular piece of legislation on the basis that we could be perceived to be going soft on crime. For instance, if people go to countries in South‐East Asia where there are very severe penalties for drug trafficking, at the moment, of course, they know that if they are convicted they will have to serve out the penalty in that particular country. There is of course a lot of money in the drug trade. I believe that the tough conditions existing in prisons and the very severe penalties imposed for drug trafficking in South‐East Asian countries might well be a powerful disincentive to many Australians to participate in that grotesque trade.

On the other hand, a prisoner transfer scheme which will permit the repatriation of prisoners to Australia might encourage some people to say, `The penalty at the end of the day is going to be treatment in a fairly soft Australian prison.' Certainly it is soft by comparison with some overseas prisons.

Obviously, this government and its predecessor made judgments that, on balance, this legislation should proceed. This legislation has really had quite a long gestation period. It was first raised in 1992 by the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General and it has taken almost five years to reach a stage where it has almost become part of the law of Australia.

This government has been in office for only the last 12 months and while I want to commend our predecessor government for initially bringing this legislation forward, I suppose citizens could well ask why it took from 1992 until the present for this legislation to be introduced. I suppose that the member who is going to speak after me might bring forward some reasons for that. Such delay seems to occur in many cases. An enormous period elapses between when we as a community decide that the law should be changed until the time that the particular law is actually altered.

As I mentioned, there will be a number of safeguards. I referred to the situation of general prisoners. There has, of course, been another section added to the bill and it relates to prisoners of international war crimes tribunals. There will be slightly different procedures with respect to those prisoners. One of the key things to note is that there will be no need for a tribunal prisoner to actually consent to the repatriation to Australia and there will be no explicit citizenship or migration requirements.

However, a couple of minutes ago I referred to section 57 of the bill which says that no non‐citizen can be repatriated to Australia without the consent of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Other colleagues have also referred to how an overseas sentence will be enforced in Australia. In other words, what will happen to the sentence after transfer to Australia? What will happen if the sentence would be somewhat different in the other country?

There are two situations that could occur. A sentence can either continue to be enforced or, alternatively, it can be converted to a different sentence in the receiving country. The Council of Europe convention allows either method and some countries may therefore use the continued enforcement method while others may use the conversion approach.

There would be widespread concern in the Australian community if as a society we moved to the conversion approach because Australians expect that people who are sentenced to a certain term of imprisonment overseas will, in fact, serve the period of incarceration that they were sentenced to in that country rather than take advantage of softer rules in this country.

However, I understand that although the bill enables both forms of sentence enforcement, subject to any agreement to the contrary it is proposed that Australia would generally use the continued enforcement method. I believe that that would be a great reassurance to Australians who believe that when people are sentenced to a period in gaol that they should serve that period in gaol. I am a great advocate of truth in sentencing, that when a court sentences a prisoner to a certain term of incarceration then the person should serve that period in gaol and not half or a third, as seems to occur so often in this country at the moment.

Given the situation I have outlined in relation to incoming prisoners under the continued enforcement method, the prisoner would, in effect, bring with him or her the sentence from the sending country minus any time served or remissions earned in the sending country up to the date of transfer. From the date of transfer this sentence would be subject to Australia's laws concerning the enforcement of sentences. Australia's laws concerning conditional release or remission would apply to the sentence as if the sentence was a sentence of Australia at the date of transfer. The relevant laws would be those applying to federal offenders.

It is interesting that one of the initiators of this proposal was the Northern Territory government. The Northern Territory government, having got this thing under way, has now withdrawn from the scheme and there have been some concerns that the scheme ought not to proceed in view of the non‐participation of the Northern Territory government. In fact, originally it was proposed that the scheme would not be implemented unless all of the state and territory governments in Australia were going to be part of it. But the view has been taken that if the Northern Territory wants to stay out then that is a matter for the Northern Territory and, hopefully, the Northern Territory will participate subsequently.

Clearly, the ideal position is to have full participation of all the states and territories. The reason for that is fairly clear. Commonwealth practice with regard to international conventions and treaties has been that Australia will present a united face internationally and thus will not become a party unless all jurisdictions have agreed and undertaken the necessary steps to ensure that their laws are consistent with Australia's international obligations. If states and territories do not participate those who do may be disadvantaged, because Australians imprisoned overseas who wish to serve their time in Australia would attempt to do so in the participating states or territories, even though their community ties were stronger in the non‐participating states and territories. In addition, it could be said to be discriminating against Australians in overseas prisons who are from the non‐participating states and territories. So, clearly, while full participation is something to which everyone would aspire, it simply cannot be achieved at this time. Indeed, one hopes that the Northern Territory will fall into line in due course.

It also has been said by some speakers that there could be a net revenue gain for Australia, because we will have an outflow of more prisoners abroad than we will have prisoners returning to Australia. Given the enlightened system of custodial treatment in Australia, and given the fact that many people feel that prisons are very soft in Australia compared with many of the countries with whom we will enter into treaties, my own gut feeling is that most Australians abroad would quite naturally want to return to Australia so that they are able to enjoy Australian prison conditions within our prisons, but very few prisoners from non‐Western countries would seek to return home and to the standards which exist in their prison systems. I think what is highly likely is that we will get a large number of Australians returning to Australia but we will not get very many people at all going to overseas prisons.

This will mean that there could in fact be an additional cost to the system. I understand that the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) will look at this matter some time down the track—I certainly hope he does—to try to make sure that the system is equitable not only to prisoners but also to states and territories in Australia and, indeed, to the Commonwealth as a whole.

So my support for the International Transfer of Prisoners Bill is an `on balance' support. I do have certain concerns about it. It is a bill that has been a long time in coming before the parliament. As a community we have decided that the humanitarian goals, the social advantages—and some would say the economic advantages—of this legislation outweigh any detriment. So I urge that the bill be supported by the committee and the parliament and I urge the Attorney‐General to review the operation of this bill in about 12 months to see whether it needs any finetuning. I thank the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My support for the International Transfer of Prisoners Bill is not `on balance': this is a very worthwhile measure and it is overdue. The concern of the Attorney‐General's Department, when it said that it would be pre‐emptive to assume that all states will get through the process, is a worry. I join with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in hoping that all states and territories do participate in this scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: We all come to these kinds of debates with our life experience and the baggage of what we have been through. On many occasions I had the experience, particularly as a state member of parliament but also as a federal member, of having families from my electorate approach me about the problems of access they had for their family members who were incarcerated. Those people had difficulties even within this country, such as the difficulty of actually travelling on weekends to country towns to meet young offenders who had been gaoled. I have had the experience of involvement with our high commission in the United Kingdom in regard to a local citizen who was gaoled over there. He went there and it came as a massive surprise to his family when he was gaoled for drug related offences.

Over the period of 13 years that I have been in the state or federal parliament, I have probably had about 15 of these very direct circumstances, of people living within 50 metres of me, coming from very good families, basically getting mixed up with the wrong groups and being gaoled, putting great stress on their families. That is one of the major emphases I want to make regarding this measure. It is not only a question of supposed featherbedding of Australians as prisoners overseas; it is also the reality of the emotional trauma for their families.
This was well articulated in Trends and Issues, July 1992, by David Biles, who I gather from reading the committee report has also been involved at this stage. He said in that document:

Family members also often feel that it is necessary for them to visit their sons, daughters or spouses in order to provide psychological or material comfort, and they often feel compelled to make repeated pleas for assistance and relief to government authorities and welfare organisations, both in Australia and overseas. Furthermore, the available evidence indicates that prisoners who have strong and supportive relationships with their families are less likely to become recidivists than are prisoners without such relationships.

We have heard from other speakers on the question of cultural problems in overseas prisons—the question, I guess, of the possibility and probability of their being one out in prison inmate cultures, of being victimised, and of whether those corrective services systems really have much consideration of people with our cultural background.

The legislation is overdue. I am very supportive of it. There was some side comment from the previous speaker as to the fact it took so long. I notice that the actual final agreement amongst the states and territories and Commonwealth did stretch from 1992 to 1993. I could proffer the possibility that there were a lot of difficulties in getting agreement from the states; we have heard now that some of them are doubtful and others are very reluctant. There is a variety of possibilities.

If it has taken a while in this country, it has certainly been on the boil in Europe. There is a 27‐country convention there, which includes a number of countries that are not European. I understand that there is also a Commonwealth agreement. Internationally this is happening on a very large scale. It is a reality of increasing international movement of people; of, perhaps, increasing interrelationship of criminal organisations as well—I guess that has got to be a factor in it all—and also of organised crime setting up in cultures, through population movement, where they have not previously been present. All those factors come into it.

It is interesting to note, however, with reference to the advocacy of the need for the international transfer of prisoners that Biles documented in 1992, if you look at the numbers involved, which are to some degree guesswork, you see that there does not seem to have been a great increase in those gaoled either here or overseas in the various categories.

I notice a bit of difficulty in the figures supplied to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—there seems a bit of a conflict there—and I think it points to the uncertainty when they talk about people born overseas and those who actually would be eligible to be covered by this legislation. There do not seem to be clear figures in a number of jurisdictions as to whether they relate to people who could go back or those who were born overseas. If you look at the actual figures and add them up for the states that had people interested in the scheme, et cetera, you find more than were originally claimed to be eligible. Equally, as people say, there is debate as to how many Australian citizens there are in overseas prisons. The degree of consular contact, the degree to which they know about people and the degree to which people actually bother to be in contact with our representatives all lead to uncertainty in the figures.

Everyone around the place is proffering ideas about whether, on balance, we are going to save money. Of course it is highly probable that the number of Australians trying to re‐enter here will be greater, but the actual figures seem to indicate that we hold far greater numbers of people who would be eligible for return to overseas nations. It really is a lot of guesswork and, at the end of the day, the humanitarian aspect concerning these people's families and the problems they have in overseas jurisdictions wins me in the debate.

Concerns have been expressed about the possibility that people will give up their appeal rights. There have been references to the number of IRA cases in the United Kingdom and the possibility that people would give up rights and would essentially have possibilities of winning those appeals. It is not just politically related cases like the IRA. You could probably refer to people who went to the gallows in the United Kingdom, through failures in their system, to see that there is a danger that people do not exercise those full rights.

When you see a legal system in the United States where 12 per cent of people are black yet 41 per cent of people facing the death sentence are black, you do question overseas jurisdictions. There is the question of whether people do sacrifice rights that they should exercise to the very limit and whether this might become an incentive for some to sacrifice those rights.

There are a variety of protections here. As other speakers have indicated, there is a requirement that there be consent by the individual, by the countries involved et cetera. I note that in the migration area—and I am a person who has had a fair involvement in this field and takes a deep interest in it—the correct protections are there. There is the requirement of the minister to have an involvement with regard to those people who are not citizens. I notice reference to the question of those children born overseas, how they fit into the system, and the need for that to be looked at. There is the question of dual criminality—that offences are roughly commensurate in the two countries.

I do not really have any doubts in a fundamental sense about this legislation. There are references to annual reporting. We are taking about a phenomenon that is increasing internationally. We have a situation where people who are separated from their families and are alone in jurisdictions are given this opportunity. I think the legislation is worth while. I do hope that all states and territories come on board and that we do not have an over‐concentration on unnecessary fears about swarms of people somehow descending on the country when they have no right to be here, or on concerns that people will miss out on the great suffering that some people think they should have in Thailand or Burma.

We should get a few of these things in perspective. Some people run around expressing concern that it might be better for some people to suffer in Thai gaols. To put this in perspective, there was an interesting article this week in the Guardian Weekly about the Burmese regime and its treatment of other people with a bit more than a passing interest in crime. It was noted in the article that Khun Sa was given licences to operate transport companies, trade in real estate and run a $24 million mineral concession under his new name. The article said:

BREAK.PARA: The men who mediated for him in the lead‐up to his televised surrender, including his former accountant and two Mong Tai officers, say a $20 million contract was drawn up.

The situation is that the main architect of drug peddling in the Burma Thailand border area was accepted by Burmese authorities and basically allowed to go legitimate within the legal system of that country. So to quibble over the fact that a few people—who, to my mind, are basically desperates in general from what you see of them on television—might not be suffering from malaria and a series of other diseases in Thai gaols is really not the right emphasis to put on this measure. It is overdue, I support it strongly, and I congratulate the government for bringing it before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I commence by thanking members who have spoken on this bill, the International Transfer of Prisoners Bill, and I note that, in effect, all have supported it. The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) represents the shadow Attorney‐General and is a regular speaker on bills from my portfolio, but there were also other regular contributors to discussion of bills in my portfolio, including the members for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), Barton (Mr McClelland), Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) and Fisher (Mr Slipper). I am very pleased that this particular bill has also attracted the attention of the member for Swan (Mr Randall) and the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson). We hope to see more contributions from them on the Attorney‐General's portfolio bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill, as has been mentioned, was the subject of an advisory report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I welcome the committee's report and its strong support of the bill. The report itself recognises the considerable consultation and work that has gone into the development of it, particularly through the comprehensive and detailed consultation process with the states and territories. I am grateful for the thorough and detailed consideration which the committee devoted to the bill.

The committee made seven recommendations and I am pleased to be able to say that I agree with all of them. I propose to just briefly mention each of them. The first is that the parliament pass the bill following due consideration of the recommendations of the committee's report. I naturally agree wholeheartedly with that recommendation. In light of the strong rehabilitative and humanitarian benefits and the possible financial advantages of international prisoner transfers, I would urge the Senate, as well as the House, to pass the bill as soon as possible.

The committee's second recommendation is that I formally approach my state and territory counterparts about participating in the international transfer of prisoners scheme. Members would be aware that this matter has been on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General for some time. I have previously written to my colleagues from the states and territories on this issue on a number of occasions. I have again recently written and drawn their attention to the committee's report. In accordance with the committee's recommendation I have emphasised the value of the scheme and the need for all states and territories to enact complementary legislation as a matter of priority.

The third recommendation is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock. It is that he initiate an examination of the issues surrounding the eligibility of persons who have been removed from Australia as children to have a right of entry to Australia. The question as to whether certain people should have a right of entry to Australia is clearly a wider issue relating to migration legislation, rather than simply an issue specifically related to the International Transfer of Prisoners Bill. I therefore have written to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs drawing this recommendation to his attention and requesting him to undertake any necessary follow‐up action. I note that any subsequent action on this issue should not impede the progress of the bill.

The fourth recommendation is that my department note any difficulties which arise in the operation of the transfer scheme as a result of either the language used in paragraph 15(1)(a) or its substantive elements, and report on any such difficulties in an annual review of the scheme. That paragraph requires that for transfers to Australia neither the sentence of imprisonment imposed by the transfer country's court or tribunal nor the conviction on which it is based is subject to appeal under the law of the transfer country. This requires that the appeal process is exhausted. It does not, however, exclude the possibility of a later review based, for example, on fresh evidence. I have requested my department to pay particular attention to the practical operation of this paragraph when the scheme is in place and to report on any particular difficulties as part of the annual reporting process.

The fifth recommendation is that when the regulations are drafted they should provide that prisoners be given information about either prison conditions in the country they want to transfer to, or relevant organisations that provide such information, prior to the making of the decision about being transferred to that country. I agree with this recommendation and will ensure that this matter is addressed in the drafting of the regulations.

The sixth recommendation is that the operation of the act be reviewed by the Attorney‐General's Department annually and that a report of that review be tabled in the parliament. I agree that regular reporting on the operation of the legislation is important. I propose to implement this recommendation by having my department include specific information on the operation of the act in its annual report, which is tabled in parliament.

Finally, it is recommended that clause 24 be redrafted for clarification purposes. I agree with this recommendation and have circulated a government amendment in response to it. I commend the bill to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 24, page 24 (line 10), omit "the transfer can be", substitute ", were the Attorney-General to give that consent, the transfer could be".
I present the explanatory memorandum.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with an amendment. The question now is that the bill be reported to the House with an amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Mr Abbott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Education Legislation Amendment Bill is not controversial legislation. We support it. There does not seem to be any disagreement coming from any quarter about the desirability of moving the University of Canberra from Commonwealth control to that of the ACT government. I think that makes a great deal of sense. It makes the arrangement more consistent with that applying to almost all the other universities in this country—the big exception of course being the Australian National University. That university does have a somewhat different function, given that it has within it the Institute of Advanced Studies, which receives a large part of total higher education research funding and which is very much a national asset. So there is some sense in continuing to maintain it as a national institution under the control of the Commonwealth government.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly we agree that moving the University of Canberra to the ACT government is a good move. The Vice‐Chancellor, Professor Aitken, has been very keen to see this matter expedited. I indicated to him that, from the point of view of the opposition, we would do everything possible to speed the process up. So the bill is being treated as non‐controversial, as indicated by the fact that it is being debated in this place.

That is the major measure in the legislation. The other change relates to the Maritime College and confers on it a capacity to make statutes in relation to regulating parking and something or other else, which is hardly what you would call contentious. We are inclined to support both those measures.

The University of Canberra has really come on very well over the last few years. I know well the Vice‐Chancellor, Professor Aitken. I particularly knew him well when I was minister for higher education from 1990 to 1993. He is an outstanding institutional leader and has made a major contribution over the years to public debate about educational issues. He has made a major contribution to this country's education system in a variety of capacities over the years.

I think the University of Canberra itself is showing the benefits of that very good institutional leadership. It is now in a number of areas of study an institution that produces graduates whose employability is among the highest in the country, certainly in particular fields. I think Professor Aitken has a vision for the future of the institution and has been instrumental in pushing it along.

So I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate all those associated with the university and wish it well for the future. I hope that the new relationship established with the ACT government, which certainly the university itself favours, will assist in promoting its further development as an institution servicing this region and the country as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My initial excitement when I saw the Maritime College Act being amended turned to disappointment. Having a maritime background, I thought there might be something that I could relate to in relation to that particular act, and at the same time indulge myself a little. I remember the setting up of that college with a great deal of fondness. However, I then noticed that the amendment related to the invariable discussion at universities about car parking. That is a bone of contention no matter what campus you go to, it seems—although the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) might say that the campus at his electorate may not have the sorts of problems that they have at St Lucia and other places, and obviously at the Maritime College in Tasmania—
—Don't you believe it!

—Right! In any event, those car parking matters often turn into nice little junior briefs for young counsel at the bar, and they can be a good source of income when you start off. The thrust of the Education Legislation Amendment Bill is the amendments to the University of Canberra Act. The clear thrust is to amend the act in order to transfer responsibility for the University of Canberra from the Commonwealth to the ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: At the risk of being labelled a bit of an old fogey, I want to look a little at universities generally in a philosophical way and lament what has happened to them. While I welcome the particular development in one sense, it is timely to cast one's mind back a little to what has happened in relation to universities, particularly in recent times.

Some of them have become businesses. I question whether that is a good thing. In some areas one would say, `Yes, it is good that we can promote the development of research and development.' For example, the areas of research at the University of Queensland have been expanded, and great assistance has been forthcoming, particularly in the engineering and metallurgical areas, where great developments have been made that have spawned a number of significant developments, particularly in metallurgy.

At the same time, from a philosophical point of view, the overall notion that a university is really a business tends to detract from what universities should engender. I am reminded of the notion of student protest. I find the widespread lack of student protest alarming in many respects.

One of the greatest curses facing mankind is hunger, and yet student protests these days at universities seem to revolve around very selfish issues. They seem to be talking about whether they are getting enough, or more frequently not getting anything, out of the public purse. Great protests are made of that in sectional areas. Frequently, somewhat trendy middle‐class pursuits and debates are followed—the sorts of things that permeate cafe society.

Where is the leading? Where is the forefront of protest in universities? Where are the students who are standing up for the hungry in society? Why aren't they at the vanguard of those issues? Why aren't we seeing raised the thought-provoking placards of the sort we used to see in the 1960s, draped across the Victoria bridge? And what about the marches?

When I was at university, I was never a person who would go around protesting. In fact, I was a conservative student, but I did admire the protest movement, because I admired the fact that there were people who were prepared to question the society and to question the Vietnam War and the various establishment norms. The fact that we had those things going on in the university culture in those days was, I think, healthy for society generally. I ask myself, with some regret, where that movement has gone, and whether the university system has in fact crushed dissent, somewhat subconsciously.

Has the whole structure of university life become so centred on goals and outcomes that the free thought that universities ought to promote, nurture and respect and the time for those activities and the fun associated with them have really been crushed by the nature of university life? Has the learning been such a drag and such an impost that wisdom, dissent and initiative have been squeezed out of students these days?

BREAK.PARA: I regret to say that I feel that that has happened a lot. Largely we see in the protest movement, or what is left of it, somewhat of a Trotskyist rump. I am not saying necessarily that that is a bad thing, either. I do not think it is a bad thing, but the fact is that it is so marginalised that nobody bothers with it anyway, whereas the university protest movement of the old days was a much broader church.

It is worthy of note that many of the people on both sides of politics were part of that protest movement, in one form or another, and have variously segregated to particular areas of politics; but frequently they joined for part of those protest movements, which was a good thing, and I think it spawned the sort of leadership potential that we see in the political sphere now. Are we going to lose that, if we do not remember that that is the way that university life is conducted? Perhaps I am lamenting the good old days. Are they gone for good—or bad, depending on one's point of view?

In any event, the University of Canberra began life as the Canberra College of Advanced Education, and it was assisted through the transition to university by sponsorship from Monash University, and that process began in 1989. The sponsorship arrangements gave Monash University powers of approval over the development of the University of Canberra's graduate programs and over staff appointments at certain levels. In 1992 the vice‐chancellors of both universities agreed that the continuation of sponsorship was unnecessary and it was time to bring the Big Brother type of relationship to an end. The bill makes appropriate and necessary amendments to the University of Canberra Act, to reflect the fact that the sponsorship arrangements no longer apply.

Monash University is an institution of considerable significance for the government. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) graduated from that university with a BA and a LLB (Hons). After completing his undergraduate studies, he went on to become a tutor in the faculties of law, economics and politics at Monash and was an academic of some renown who, in undergraduate life, was quite intensely involved in the campus scene.

To return to my original point, for many years the university campus has been the breeding ground for leaders of the future, but the leaders were also found outside the university. It was a nice combination. We think of people like Ben Chifley in that regard, and you see on our side of politics a lot of people who have never been near a university but who have acquired the wisdom from the university of life. While it is still the case today that we are looking for potential leaders from the university culture, I wonder if the emphasis upon academic attainment is so ingrained in university life that it is at the expense of the joie de vivre exhibited by university students in the 1960s and 1970s. I will leave that with the Committee.

The bill also introduces amendments to the Remuneration Tribunal Act to give effect to the policy that it is appropriate for higher education institutions in the states and territories to determine for themselves what role, if any, that tribunal should have in relation to determining salaries in those areas. It is worthy to observe also, in this fairly general debate, that one of the most often lamented or criticised matters when I was an undergraduate was the standard of performance of some of the academics.

We now have a culture of the business orientated university, which highlights that in my time at university, in the 1970s, there was certainly a need to look at the standard of academics. They seemed frequently to be ungovernable by any standards of performance, output and ability to lecture. The students would complain constantly about performance, yet nothing was ever done. I hope that universities, particularly as a result of this measure, recognise that there is a need to ensure standards of academic excellence and that the old catchcry of the independence of academics and their position in the debate is not used as a means of stifling justifiable criticism of some of the performance of academics.

One lecturer that I had would not qualify to make tea in the office of a suburban solicitor, yet he was lecturing in a very significant area of law at the University of Queensland—having been passed on from a Melbourne university, with glowing references. It is those sorts of things I am talking about. I know I am going back some years, but I suspect that it is an area that universities should be looking at. Overall, I thank the Committee for this opportunity to participate in this debate and support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I arise also to support the Education Legislation Amendment Bill and, as the member for Canberra, to speak principally about the transfer of the University of Canberra to the ACT government. I will talk in detail, in the brief time available, about some aspects to do with the university, but I want firstly to contrast the positive recognition in this bill of the self‐government of the ACT, and the rights and capacity of the ACT to discharge this sort of obligation equally with the states, with the dreadful decision that parliament made last night with regard to the Andrews bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: My principal concern about that bill was not its reflection on the rights of territories, as I made clear in my speech in the Main Committee. My concern was one of the substance of the matter. But we now have a situation where citizens of the three territories—if you include Norfolk Island, which is also part of my electorate—suffer a disease not known to any other Australian, called Andrews agony. They are the only people who have had this parliament impose upon them suffering which they desire to be freed from and from which the parliament which they had elected gave them an outlet. I deplore and regret that decision, and I choose very briefly to make that contrast with the very positive recognition for the ACT reflected in this legislation.

I want only to speak about that part of the bill that relates to the University of Canberra. It is a transfer that was originally proposed by the university, and I think correctly. It was supported by the previous government and it was supported by this government, and reintroduced by it. It had been introduced by the previous government but not finished before the election. It is supported also by the Labor and Liberal parties in the ACT. It is, clearly, not a politically controversial matter, nor institutionally, in terms of the views of the University of Canberra or any of the other principal education institutions of the ACT.

The University of Canberra is a very important institution in ACT society and in the ACT economy. It sees itself as a significant part of the community. It participates actively within the community and makes a substantial contribution to it. I welcome, and was very interested in, some of the remarks made by the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith)—and I do not pretend that I shared them all—and I thought he was raising some interesting questions about the nature of universities and their relationship to their staff and students in this time of greater focus on the commercial role of universities.

I was interested in his perception of the changing role of students in our society, as evidenced by his comment upon the lack of demonstrations—which was an interesting comment to hear from a member of the government—and his concern that the universities were becoming too business oriented and were changing their focus from the more academic and research orientation to a more commercial orientation. I was very interested to hear those remarks from a government member and I welcome the fact that he raised those issues. As I say, I do not share all the views he expressed, but I thought they were interesting.

If we want to look at why the volume and nature of public policy involvement by students change, we need to look at more than what is going on in universities; we need to have a look at what is going on much more broadly in the economy and in society. That would be a debate worth having, but it would be a different debate.

One of the things that the University of Canberra does significantly here in the ACT relates to that commercial role in terms of the influx of foreign fee‐paying students. They are important to the university. In the last year for which I have figures, foreign fee‐paying students were 9.7 per cent of the university's total student load and contributed $5.41 million in 1995 to the university. They also contribute substantially to the broader economy of the ACT in terms of that $5.41 million and in terms of the other activities of those students while they are here participating at the university, and in terms of people who come to visit the ACT as a result of those students being here.

Like all universities, the University of Canberra is facing financial difficulties as a result of the government funding changes. It is putting the university under pressure. It is requiring decisions to be made that the administration, the students and the staff do not welcome. I hope that we can see some easing of that relentless pressure upon tertiary institutions in general and, for the purpose of this debate, the University of Canberra in particular, in the forthcoming budget.

The University of Canberra makes a substantial broader regional contribution. It says in its mission statement and objectives that the university sets itself to be the principal knowledge resource for the ACT and its hinterland and to possess the strongest possible links between the university and the community. It is very significant in the ACT. It is important that it raises that broader question of its significance in the region.

One of the causes of concern to me, when people assess the economy of the ACT, is the failure of people to understand the complex and important interrelationship between that economy and the economy of the whole of the south‐east of New South Wales, most obviously with Queanbeyan but quite importantly with the much broader south‐eastern New South Wales region of which Canberra operates as the major regional city.

It is also a university of national significance. I cannot do justice to that in the time available, but I have been aware of, and in some ways rather involved in, the important work it does at the Australian Centre for Local Government Studies, with the CRCs, with the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling and with the Ngunnawal Centre for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education. So you can see broader national involvement and contribution by the University of Canberra, and that reinforces the extent to which I welcome its role here and this legislation transferring responsibility to the ACT government.

The final point I want to make, because I did promise those seeking to organise the agenda that I would finish in 10 minutes, is about the underestimated contribution of universities in regional cities—not just Canberra, but also in most of Australia's major regional cities—in the employment area. Directly, with academic staff and non‐academic staff, plus measuring the full‐time equivalents of the casual staff in the various categories, there are a thousand jobs at the University of Canberra. Very many other jobs are indirectly contributed to by its existence. The whole high technology park across the road from the university would not exist and thrive in the way it does without its interrelationship with the IT and engineering schools of the university. Some of those functions would be there anyway, some would not, with the CRCs and the other relationships.

I welcome this legislation and the fact that it is going to pass through the parliament in this session. I welcome the fact that it has had bipartisan support, as it had in the past. I look forward to the continuing successful development of the university under the jurisdiction of the ACT government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—My first political involvement was at a demonstration. It was an anti‐Kerr demonstration on the campus of the University of New South Wales.
—Who's side were you on?

—I am pleased to say I was an anti anti‐Kerr demonstrator because I thought that Sir John Kerr was being unjustly vilified. Anyway, I take the point made by the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) which is obviously right: there is more to life than just money, and there should be more to university life than simply passing exams. I welcome his contribution to this debate on the Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill, as the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) said, is a very uncontroversial one. It transfers responsibility for the University of Canberra from the Commonwealth to the ACT government and it also provides to the Australian Maritime College the ability to make by‐laws to control its own parking. I should point out that this bill in no way diminishes the Commonwealth's funding obligations to the University of Canberra.

The bill has had a rather long march through the legislative process to fruition this evening. It was in April 1993 when the University of Canberra first sought this transfer from Commonwealth to territory jurisdiction, because the university believed that it would be better integrated into the ACT government's education strategies if it came under the ACT's jurisdiction. It believed that, in this way, there would be a closer identification between the university and the ACT. It believed that it would serve the purposes of the university to have as its parliamentary champion, as it were, the ACT minister for education, rather than the federal minister who had many other things on his or her plate. I guess the university thought that it was perhaps better to be a big fish in a small pool, than a small fish in a big pool. Legislation was finally brought into the parliament in late 1995 by the former government, but it lapsed as a result of the election, so this legislation is now before the House.

This legislation is a sign of the government's commitment to the ACT. It is a sign of successful lobbying on the part of Professor Aitken, Senator Margaret Reid and many other people. From the government's point of view, placing the University of Canberra under territory jurisdiction puts it in the same position as nearly all other universities, with the exception of the Australian National University.

These universities are juridically responsible to state and territory governments, even though the Commonwealth provides the vast preponderance of funds. I am sure the ACT government is appropriately grateful for this chance to exercise stewardship over the University of Canberra while the Commonwealth continues to provide the money.

Turning to the second aspect of this bill, in late 1993 the Australian Maritime College in Launceston was troubled by a very serious problem. It seems that the adjacent University of Tasmania campus introduced parking restrictions on its students and, as a result, some of those students chose to park in the grounds of the Australian Maritime College.

The Australian Maritime College then sought legal advice on its ability to control parking on its own grounds. I am going to read, if I may, some of that advice, because it is important that everyone understands exactly why the government is taking up the parliament's time with this legislation. When the AMC asked the lawyers for advice, it posed this question:
Does the College have power to make traffic regulations that are enforceable?
The lawyers answered:

We note the provisions of Section 24 of the Maritime College Act 1978 which allows the Council to make statutes . . . with respect to the . . . (a) management, good government and discipline of the College and of the institution conducted by the College.

It further allows . . . for the imposition, by or on behalf of the College, of penalties upon students of the College or persons employed by the College for contravention of, or failure to comply with, a statute with respect to a matter referred to in paragraph (a).
However, the lawyers went on to say:
It does not contemplate, by inference, penalties upon "outsiders" such as trespassing students from the University or any other people illegally parked upon College property.
The lawyers then advised as follows:

If one turns to Section 24(1)(j) which provides that statutes may be enacted for "any other matter necessary or convenient for giving effect to this Act" then one can see that it was obviously the intent of Parliament to provide general powers to the College to govern its own affairs. Its own affairs must, by definition, include the management of its grounds. Nevertheless we are concerned that some legal challenge could, conceivably, be mounted to any parking scheme by reason of the unfortunate wording of Section 24(1)(b) which refers to penalties being imposed only upon students or staff. As a matter of practicality it might be highly unlikely that the scheme would be challenged but nevertheless we feel obliged to point out the possibility.

That is what the lawyers said, and that is why this act has come before the parliament. The Australian Maritime College can use an action in trespass against anyone parking improperly on the grounds, but it is always much easier to impose a fine—and hence this legislation.

If, as the good Lord says, not a sparrow falls without the knowledge of the Father, I am sure the voters of Australia will be delighted to know that not a car is illicitly parked in the grounds of the AMC in Launceston without the benevolent intervention of the federal government. I commend this important bill to the parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996 contains three changes which were announced by the previous government in the 1995‐96 budget as a response to a small number of recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. The bill also includes consequential changes to child support legislation to reflect changes made in the Social Security Act 1991, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The package of measures included in the bill is aimed at increasing flexibility, reducing the level of intrusiveness and improving certainty and clarity in the law.
Use of election where income has changed

Where a child support liability has been created by an administrative assessment, a parent is able to apply to have the registrar vary the amount of their liability by lodging an income estimate election. An income estimate election often results in a paying parent being entitled to a refund of moneys already paid to the person receiving child support. This causes significant inconvenience for persons receiving child support where the amount of child support has already been spent for the benefit of the children. It also means that the parent paying child support often has to repay most, if not all, of the amount refunded over the remainder of the year at a time when they have less capacity to do so.

The bill will amend the effect of an income estimate election to make it less likely that a person receiving child support will be asked to repay amounts in the future and to make the effect of an income estimate election a more accurate reflection of a paying parent's capacity to pay.

The revised income estimate will be used to recalculate the amount of the child support properly payable for the year. However, amounts payable prior to the date of lodgment of an estimate will generally be left undisturbed and will be taken into account in arriving at the future liabilities for the remaining period.

The only time that amounts payable prior to the lodgment of an estimate will be disturbed is where, after calculating the amount properly payable and the amounts charged to the date of the estimate, the parent has already been charged too much for the year.
This will remove a significant and frequent cause for complaint from persons receiving child support.
Electing for employer withholding not to apply

The bill amends the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to allow a payer of child support to make payments directly to the Child Support Registrar where the registrar is satisfied that a person will make timely payments. This measure will :
. reduce the level of intrusiveness of the child support scheme for payers who can be relied upon to make their child support payments directly to the registrar in a timely manner;
. provide greater flexibility to the registrar in the way he administers the collection of child support and reduce overall administration costs; and
. reduce the costs of compliance by employers in withholding child support by permitting more payers to pay directly where they can be relied on to make payments in a timely manner.
If the registrar refuses to accept an election to pay directly, the payer has the right to object to, and appeal against, this decision.

BREAK.PARA: The government is conscious that the implications may be severe for children where a payer defaults. The registrar's primary responsibility will continue to be to ensure the collection of child support in a timely manner. In making the proposed change, the government will ensure that there are strict safeguards in the event of default.

In the event of default, the registrar will be able to require that child support be withheld from a person's employer in the future and a payer will not be able to make another election until a period of 6 months has elapsed from the date the registrar was required to make arrangements with a person's employer. In most cases, payers who default after choosing to pay directly to the registrar will have strictly limited future access to this provision.
Consideration of child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings

The bill will amend the Family Law Act to enable the court to take into account the child support liability of a person in property and spousal maintenance proceedings, even where a child support assessment has not been issued. Under the existing law, where a person is voluntarily paying child support without an assessment of his child support liability, the amounts paid or to be paid under such arrangements cannot be taken into account by the court in making orders in either property or spousal maintenance proceedings.

This may result in courts making orders which do not adequately reflect the true circumstances of the party who is to pay child support. This also means that parties must apply for an assessment even where they wish to make private arrangements regarding child support for the court to take into account these commitments when making orders regarding property or spousal maintenance. This will ensure that separated parents with private arrangements for child support will be treated in the same way as parents who are paying child support under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.
CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS
Employer record keeping requirements

The bill amends the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to reduce the period an employer is required to retain child support records from seven years to five years. This will bring the child support requirement into line with record keeping requirements under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

This measure will make it easier for employers to voluntarily comply with their record keeping obligations by having one period for both taxation and child support purposes. It will also result in a slight reduction in the cost of compliance as the period of retention of records for child support purposes has been reduced.
Family Law Act 1975 changes
The bill brings the child support presumptions of parentage into line with the amended provisions of the Family Law Act 1975.
Updating references to the Social Security Act

The bill amends the provisions in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 by substituting references to the Social Security Act 1947 with provisions and concepts in the Social Security Act 1991. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) expresses concern at the failure of the Howard Government, after 12 months in office, to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues entitled `Child Support Scheme: An Examination of the Operation and Effectiveness of the Scheme';
(2) believes the Government should be concerned about the well‐being and welfare of all families: whether they be intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families;
(3) notes with concern the failure to implement some of the report's recommendations has caused parents and their children to suffer needless hardship;
(4) believes that there is important and urgent need to improve and strengthen the Child Support Scheme; and

(5) considers that much time has been lost and therefore the Government should respond to the recommendations of the report concerned with changing the child support formula as soon as possible and introduce legislation within six months to this effect".

I expect that amendment moved by the opposition to be embraced by the government members, particularly their self‐appointed experts on the back bench who have stood up on numerous occasions lamenting the shortcomings of the child support scheme. I anticipate the support of the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek), the member for Bowman (Mrs West), the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), the member for Longman (Mr Brough) and the member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly)—just to name a few. This has been one of the interesting features of the new government backbench since the last election: their determination to talk big on the question of child support reform but to act very little when it comes to bringing to the parliament substantive amendments.

It is, of course, unacceptable that the government after 12 months in office has failed to respond to the findings and recommendations of the parliamentary report of 1994. The measures now before the parliament represent an ALP response from the time of the 1995‐96 budget. So, for a government that promised so much and for a government backbench which has spoken so frequently on this matter, one would expect the Howard government to do a lot more than to imitate the Labor proposals that were foreshadowed at the time of the 1995 budget. Once again the Labor Party is in a position where it is here to help the government honour its election commitments to improve the operation, effectiveness and equity of the Child Support Agency.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to introduce certain recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, reflecting the changes announced by the former government in August 1995. A major impact of the package is that it streamlines a number of administrative elements of the child support scheme, foreshadowing three changes to existing arrangements: firstly, the use of election where income is changed; secondly, electing for employer withholding not to apply; and, finally, consideration of child support liabilities in family law proceedings.

I will deal with the first of these reforms. Parents have the right to apply to the Child Support Registrar to vary the amount of their liability so that either the custodial parent is forced to repay moneys which have already been spent on the supported children in question, or, conversely, that a paying parent is forced to repay most or all of the amount refunded over the remainder of the year.

Under the current system, variation to a paying parent's liability has been extremely inconvenient for both the custodial and non‐custodial parent. The purpose of this aspect of the amendment is to allow for a more accurate reflection of the payer's future capacity to pay because the amount payable will only be charged for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. It will also reduce the likelihood of a custodial parent being compelled to make repayments.

The second reform is electing for employer withholding not to apply. An amendment to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 will give payers the opportunity to make payments direct to the Child Support Registrar. The only caveat to this is that the registrar be satisfied that the person will make timely payments.

The benefits of this change include a saving in administrative costs which would have otherwise been spent in an attempt to make the employers aware of the scheme's operation and their subsequent responsibilities. It also provides a greater choice of method of payment for the non‐custodial parent. Many payers opt to make payments directly to the registrar rather than through an employer link, which has the advantages of privacy and confidentiality. Essentially, this change reflects greater discretion in the way the collection of child support is administered.

On the final reform, presently any voluntary child support arrangement is not taken into account by the Family Court in either property or spouse maintenance proceedings. The bill will have the effect of putting these arrangements in the same way as a child support assessment and will thus allow the court to more accurately assess the financial circumstances of the parties to the proceedings.

As the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) mentioned, the bill also contains three areas of consequential amendments to related acts. In respect to the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, this is an administrative change to bring child support record keeping requirements by employers in line with the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The period for which employers must retain child support records will be reduced from seven to five years. The administrative burden on employers in relation to their child support responsibilities will be reduced, and a system of uniform record keeping established between these acts.

The Family Law Act 1995 is amended so that the definition of parentage is streamlined by the amendment to bring it in line with the current family law provisions. These incidental amendments cover the definition of a prescribed court, the replacement of parentage in terms of months with a measure of weeks, and the presumptions which arise from cohabitation.

The Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 is being amended to ensure that certain provisions in the act with reference to the Social Security Act 1947 are updated with the provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. One feature of the amendment is that it focuses on the paying parent and examines their rights, rather than solely those of the custodial parent. The rationale is to make it easier for the custodial parent to comply with his or her recognised responsibilities.

In relation to the use of election where income has changed, the existing regime has proved to be a real burden for certain types of workers—for example, seasonal workers who are asked to estimate their income for a financial year. At least under this new provision, income estimates provided by such payers will provide a better reflection of their actual capacity to pay. This rationale also applies to consideration of child support liabilities and family law proceedings, allowing for more accurate initial assessment of the financial circumstances of the custodial and non‐custodial parent.

BREAK.PARA: As members will appreciate, the joint select committee undertook a far‐reaching inquiry which began as long ago as 1993 and received a quite impressive total of 6,200 submissions.
