That was the largest number of submissions ever received by any committee of this parliament. In addition, a hotline organised by the committee—the first hotline to operate from Parliament House, Canberra—generated 150,000 calls in two days of operation.

In tabling the committee's report, my colleague the member for Chifley, Mr Price, spoke of the need for the Child Support Agency to become a client focused and client sensitive organisation. The report contained over 160 recommendations, which were described as a fine blueprint for reform, designed to chart the way ahead for the child support scheme. Although this was a lengthy process, gradually many of the recommendations in some shape or form have been finding their way into the scheme.

This legislation—the Labor response to the select committee—is the final instalment on the recommendations. I believe it is appropriate for the Main Committee and the parliament to acknowledge their appreciation for the work of the joint select committee, particularly the chairperson, Mr Price. It is not an easy area of public policy administration and consideration, but they produced a fine report that has deserved a lot better since the election than the passage of 12 months without any active response to the remaining recommendations by the new federal government.

The submissions received by the committee raised several concerns about specific aspects of the child support formula. The areas of the formula which generated the most concern included the non‐custodial parent's self‐support component, the custodial parent's disregarded income level and the maximum income base against which the child support formula is applied. The joint committee report was an important analysis of a very complex government program. The opposition's call, through the amendment I moved earlier, for legislation to amend the child support assessment formula within the next six months follows considerable debate on this complex issue. No member could doubt the significance of the bill before us, but it is disappointing indeed, for the opposition and for tens of thousands of families subject to the child support scheme, that some of the recommendations in the report have still not been addressed at this stage. As the Department of Social Security pointed out in its submission to the child support inquiry:

There are no absolutes in relation to child support. Rather the issue is the balance points between separated and intact families; between children of first and subsequent families; between custodial and non‐custodial parents; and between parents and taxpayers generally. These balance points are complex and, in both social and economic terms, are affected by the interactions of the taxation, social security and child support systems.
The Inquiry provides the opportunity to re‐test the balance points and to clear the air on certain issues which have emerged.

With many other members of parliament, I have encountered numerous cases of the `balance points' the department refers to, through the work that I have undertaken with constituents in my electorate office.

I appreciate that any changes to the formula will change the balance between the interests of custodial and non‐custodial parents and taxpayers. There are very few instances, particularly when it comes to consideration of the formula, where policy makers can examine win‐win scenarios. This is an area of policy, in the absence of major injections of public funding, where most of the reforms throw up the prospect of win‐lose scenarios. So the application of sound policy principles is all important. I can foreshadow that, as the opposition member now chartered with some shadow responsibilities for child support, I will be trying to apply some fresh principles to this complex area of public policy.

As is so often the case with these win‐lose scenarios, the child support area has been seen through the prism of gender equity issues. I am disappointed that so many of these debates seem to have fallen to the level of pitching male versus female interests. It is much healthier for the parliament and parliamentarians to consider child support through the prism of income equity concerns and to examine the fairness of the existing income transfers implicit in the formula. We should blindfold ourselves to whether the parent is male or female, and rather take an income equity focus on these questions.

I look forward—although I know some members would not do so—to playing an active role in the child support area. It is complex. There are no easy answers. But I believe that by applying some fresh principles of social justice and income equity to these questions, and by blindfolding ourselves to the gender equity concerns, the parliament can have a far healthier and productive debate than we have had to this point in time.

There is no doubt that changes to the formula are contentious. But my assessment is that the joint select committee report raised all the issues in a very fair fashion and came up with workable recommendations in that respect. In my own electorate of Werriwa there are approximately 6,000 registered non‐custodial parents who are paying child support for their children. From my discussions and correspondence with many of these parents, I can assure the Main Committee that they are waiting anxiously for the promised reform of the Child Support Agency to become law and, indeed, administrative practice.

It is now commonly accepted that change is needed to the child support scheme. The real issue is the degree of change. I say to honourable members that we cannot afford to be complacent about the recommendations of the joint committee in this regard. The package of some 160 recommendations aims to strengthen the scheme, not weaken it. At the last federal election, the coalition's policy was meant to outline their position in relation to child support matters. However, apart from identifying the joint committee's report, the six‐page document released by the coalition had very little to offer.

The reason I am moving the amendment standing in my name, and the reason the opposition is confident that government members, if they match their rhetoric, will have no problem with it, is found in the coalition's Child Support Agency election platform. On the front page of the policy the coalition described the findings of the joint committee as:
. . . a solid basis for ongoing reform of the Agency.

If that is the case, if the recommendations are such a solid basis for ongoing reform of the agency, why hasn't the government responded to them 12 months after the last election? Their policy document went on to say:
The coalition will fully address the concerns of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues.
After the passage of one year, any reasonable person would have to conclude that that could not have been a core promise.

It must have been a non‐core promise because the government has not addressed any of the concerns of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law issues. It has ducked for cover. It has failed to fulfil the high expectations it set in so many electorates—particularly those along the coastal strip of Queensland and especially in the mining towns—that it would act on the findings of the joint committee. It is regrettable that the government has been so tardy in this particular process.

I also take up the words of the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), who was then the shadow minister for social security. Before the last election, in a media release issued on 22 February 1996, he stated:
A Coalition Government will reform the Child Support Agency and the Child Support Scheme.
He stated that the priorities for the coalition in office would be to ensure that the child support formula was made equitable to, as he said:
. . . offer a better deal for custodial and non‐custodial parents alike.

I make the point again: after the passage of 12 months in office, the new government has not made any change, or proposed any changes, to the child support formula. That statement was made some 13 months ago and not a single change has yet been introduced by this government.

So there has been not only a failure to match the high expectations before the election, but also a failure to match up to the rhetoric since the election. You only had to turn on the radio through the New Year‐January period to know that the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) in particular was boasting on the airwaves about the sort of support and momentum he was supposedly generating within the government for major changes to the child support formula. Whatever happened to that big talk? Whatever happened to that momentum? He produced a survey and was quoted in the West Australian newspaper on 2 January this year as saying that he had assessed the views of 60 coalition backbenchers and that 95 per cent of them wanted the Child Support Agency laws and formula changed.

The opposition's second reading amendment calls for change. After more than 12 months, it is time to transform the necessary changes and the high rhetoric of people such as the member for Herbert into the law of the Commonwealth. I look forward to the support of the 60 coalition backbenchers who say they want change and to them actually voting for change by supporting the opposition amendment.

In these matters I suppose the government might be reaching for excuses. One of them might be that its chosen minister, initially, for looking after the child support area was Senator Short. He hit the wall on other matters—not child support but financial support for himself, and his declaration of it to the parliament. I sent him many pieces of correspondence from my electorate, from people concerned about the administration of child support, but among the scores of letters that I had sent on to his office by the time of his fall I received only one back. It is worth quoting. It is the Jim Short memorial letter on child support matters, which he might care to take with him on his way to an overseas job for the boy. It says:

Since becoming responsible for child support administration, many of you have told me of the need to improve the Child Support Agency's operations. Many electorate offices deal regularly with client complaints on issues which we expect could have been resolved by a simple phone call to the CSA.

I am keen to address the problems that many clients are facing with the CSA and, through this, to reducing the number of CSA complaints which are being handled by staff in electorate offices and by Members and Senators themselves.
The Coalition Government's policy on child support commits us to administrative reform of the CSA and to addressing the concerns of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues.

Senator Short did not deliver. All he could promise, effectively, was the resolution of these matters by a phone call—as he put it, a simple phone call. It takes more than that. It takes a bill, draft legislation, consideration by the parliament and acting on the findings of the joint committee report.

Unfortunately, Jim Short's fascination with shares and pecuniary interests meant that he was not around long enough to put his rhetoric into action. The belief of the previous minister that the child support complaints brought to the attention of electorate offices can be resolved by `one simple phone call' illustrates the severe short‐sightedness of this government. I do not know of any aggrieved client of the Child Support Agency who believes their problems can be resolved by a phone call alone. Indeed, the joint committee's report highlighted the inadequacies of the communication channels that exist between staff and clients.

After more than 12 months in office this government has failed to take any steps to honour its election commitment to implement the recommendations of the joint select committee's report. This is the opportunity for those government backbenchers who have been vocal in bringing to the attention of the House specific cases of the system's failings to do more than just talk about it. Let me quote from some of the rhetoric that we have heard in recent times. I know I am supported in the amendment that I have moved by the member for Capricornia, or at least supported in his media release of 12 September 1996, which reads:
After the meeting—
with the Lone Fathers Association, in the town of Rockhampton—

Mr Marek said he is keen to see the issues raised by the Lone Fathers' Association addressed by the Government as quickly as possible and will continue to make representations in the matter until they are properly resolved.

That was some six to seven months ago and still there is no action. Item (5) of the opposition's amendment today is very kind to the member for Capricornia and his colleagues. We are giving him and the government six more months in which to legislate on changes to the child support formula. It is in their hands and, indeed, the hands of the entire coalition backbench to vote for our amendment and bind the government to change the law.

Having discussed some specific areas of reform, I want to mention the need to strengthen the CSA's administration, to allow it to better serve its clients through effective communication. These communication problems spark the need for a child support clients charter to improve service delivery. This was an initiative of the previous Labor government. In January 1996 George Gear, as Assistant Treasurer, introduced the charter designed to improve the working relationship between clients and the CSA by setting out in plain English what parents can expect and their responsibilities in ensuring a future for the children.

Specifically, the charter identifies the responsibility of those CSA clients and staff on issues such as codes of conduct, service standards, compensation, and a dispute resolution and review mechanism. The charter complemented an earlier $50 million boost to CSA resources, targeted at all agency offices in an attempt to allocate more staff to phones and upgraded communications technology within the agency. Better communications require complementary resources, especially staff.

Documents obtained by the federal opposition showed, in October last year, that the government is actually closing suburban Sydney CSA offices, abandoning thousands of clients outside the Sydney CBD. The hardest hit areas will be west and south‐west Sydney, where the Penrith, Bankstown and Hurstville offices will in the next few years be closed, losing somewhere in the vicinity of 250 jobs. The Bankstown office caters for my electorate, as it would, I expect, for the electorate of the member of Fowler (Mr Ted Grace), and I shudder to think that in a few years time constituents from Campbelltown and Liverpool will be forced to travel to the city if they need to see a CSA review officer. This will be over an hour of travel by public transport each way.

Following its extensive inquiry, the joint committee came to the conclusion that the current self-support component which applies to the non-custodial parent with no subsequent family, equivalent to the single pension rate, is set at too low a level. By quoting the self-support components of the single pension rate, the child support formula fails to truly reflect the additional costs of employment which are carried out by employed non-custodial parents and the additional fringe benefits available to pensioners.

Accordingly, recommendation 123 of the joint committee report suggests that the self-support component, referred to as the excluded income amount in the amendments, be increased. It argued that such a change would go a long way to achieving the best resolution of the balance points referred to earlier. The parents I speak to commonly cite the frustration which is felt with regard to the self-support component of the formula. The sooner we act on this frustration the better.

I receive scores of letters from frustrated parents from all over the country who are disillusioned with the government's and, in particular, with the Assistant Treasurer's unwillingness to act on their concern after all the election promises for reform.
The only public comments that have been attributed to ministers was a matter that appeared in the Courier‐Mail on 13 February this year. It said:
Social Security Minister Jocelyn Newman and Assistant Treasurer Rod Kemp are understood to be examining initial proposals but are concerned at possible budgetary effects.

This confirms again that the government is treating child support as a non-core promise. We all know that if the government is shying away because of possible budgetary effects, because of their slash and burn approach to fiscal policy, those citizens right around Australia concerned about the workings of the Child Support Agency should not hold their breath expecting this government to produce positive legislative changes to the formula.

Labor's second reading amendment has the potential to make a difference to the lives of almost a million Australians who are affected by the child support scheme. The agency's caseload has grown from just 58 cases in 1988 to cover 360,000 cases today, the equivalent of 720,000 clients. It is projected that this caseload will increase by an average of 5,000 cases a month. In addition to this workload, the CSA receives an estimated 11,000 telephone calls and in excess of 4,000 letters a day.

These are staggering figures by any account and the problems that have arisen largely because of the CSA's rate of growth have exceeded all expectations. That confirms beyond all doubt that this is, if I can use the term, a mainstream issue and concern to the Australian people. It is not something that should necessarily be sent away to the Main Committee alone. I look forward to the House voting on my second reading amendment.

With that level of caseload, with 720,000 clients and growing by 5,000 cases a month, this is an issue that every single member of this parliament must address. Every single member must be urging the minister responsible, Senator Kemp, to act on the findings of the joint committee and to bring a much fairer system of child support to all those citizens around Australia who rely on this parliament for a much fairer deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

BREAK.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 5 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the (a) average upfront fee paid by new residents and (b) level of demand or waiting list size for each hostel in each State and Territory owned and operated (i) for profit, (ii) by government and (iii) by community and religious organisations.
(2) Has her Department developed an affordability index for intending hostel residents; if so, (a) what is it and (b) how was it developed; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Entry contributions are refundable deposits negotiated between the resident and the provider. They are private arrangements and for this reason the government does not collect administrative information from them.
The government does not collect information on hostel waiting lists, which are essentially a private administrative concerns for hostels.

(2) The Government does not collect information on entry contributions paid and does not have an affordability index for such contributions because they are private arrangements between the provider and the consumer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 10 December 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) How many persons arrived in north-west Australia illegally by boat in each year since 1975 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.

(2) How many of those persons were (a) subsequently granted permanent residency (i) as refugees or (ii) under other categories, (b) subsequently deported and (c) still remain in Australia, and if so for what reason.
(3) What were the detailed, specific costs to the Commonwealth associated with the handling of illegal boat persons in each year since 1975.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Between 1975 and 20 January 1997, a total of 112 boats, carrying 4,752 unauthorised arrivals, have arrived in north-west Australia, including Christmas Island, Ashmore and Cartier Reefs. Departmental records do not indicate the year of arrival for the 2,067 persons who arrived prior to 1980. There were no such arrivals in the years 1982 to 1988 inclusive. Arrivals in other years were:
1981—146 persons
1989—26 persons
1990—198 persons
1991—214 persons
1992—191 persons
1993—81 persons
1994—953 persons
1995—237 persons
1996—639 persons
There were 72 children born to these unauthorised arrivals by boat while they were in detention in Australia.
(2) Of the 4,752 persons, plus 72 Australian born children
(a)(i) 1,413 were granted permanent residency as refugees, and
(a)(ii) 1,153 were granted permanent residency under other categories;
(b) 1,987 were deported or repatriated from Australia; and
(c) 271 remain in Australias for the following reasons
66 are awaiting the outcome of primary applications for protection,
2 are awaiting decisions by the Refugee Review Tribunal,
1 is awaiting the outcome of a request for Ministerial intervention under S.417,
164 are available for removal once arrangements are concluded and travel documentation is available,
31 are awaiting the outcome of litigation; and 7 are at large in the community following their escape from custody and are available for removal once recaptured.
(3) Costs for unauthorised arrivals by boat were not separated from other Departmental costs until 1992/93. Identifiable expenditure since that time is:

PARA.TAB: 1992/93—Reception, detention and repatriation, excluding property operating costs—$8.608m
1993/94—Reception, detention and repatriation, excluding property operating costs—$6.384m
1994/95—Reception, detention and repatriation, including property operating costs—$15.485m
1995/96—Reception, detention and repatriation, including property operating costs—$29.776m
1996/97 (to 31 Dec 1996) Reception Detention Repatriation Property operating costs:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What funds have been allocated by her or her Department to research the study of dementia in aged citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A total funding of $453,652 was provided for the following four research projects under the National Action Plan for Dementia Care and the Psychogeriatric Care and Support Initiative in 1996/97:
"Care Needs of People with Dementia and Challenging Behaviours Living in Residential Facilities", $40,750;
"Challenging Behaviours in Dementia: A Shared Care Model of
Models of Management of Depression and Psychosis (and Associated Behavioural Problems) in Nursing Home Residents with Dementia", $112,872; and
"Caring for Someone with a Dementing Condition", $160,267.

A total of 39 projects were completed or have funds allocated to them in the calendar years of 1996 ($2,045,423) and 1997 ($2,385,751). The majority of this funding is provided through the National Health and Medical Research Council, and a small amount of funding is also provided through the National Action Plan for Dementia Care.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government compile figures on youth suicide in Australia.
(2) What age group is defined as youth.

(3) Are the figures categorised into urban and rural areas; if so, (a) how are those areas defined and (b) what are the respective figures for those areas in (i) Australia, (ii) Victoria, and (iii) the
(4) How do the figures for Australia compare with known international figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Suicide data are collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) based on the findings of State and Territory Coroners.
(2) A suicide is considered a youth suicide if it is in the 15‐24 year age range.

(3) (a) A variety of definitions of rural and urban locations have been used by various researchers and data collection agencies for particular studies. The following tables are based upon defining a Statistical Local Area as rural if it has less than 20,000 inhabitants.

(b) Tables containing relevant available data for Australian and Victorian urban and rural youth suicide comparisons follow. No data is available for the years 1985 and 1980. Data for the period 1993 to 1996 is not yet available in publishable form. No information was held in my Department regarding youth suicide rates for the electoral division of Wannon.
(b) (i) Australian urban and rural youth suicide comparisons.
Australian Youth Suicide Rates by Urban and Rural Areas
* Source ABS, Cause of Deaths, rate is shown as rates of death per 100,000 of population for age group 15‐24 years.
(b) (ii) Victorian urban and rural youth suicide comparisons.
Victorian Youth Suicide: Numbers of Deaths by Urban and Rural Areas
Source: ABS, Deaths by suicide for ages 15‐24 yo, 1988‐92

(4) The World Health Organisation's Statistics Annual for 1994, which recorded deaths for the years 1991‐1993, showed Australia's reported suicide rate for young men as 11th highest of 45 countries which provided statistics for that edition. Australia's reported suicide rate for young women was 15th highest amongst the same 45 countries.
Australian youth suicide rates remain amongst the highest in the western industrialised world.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nursing Home Beds: Electoral Division of Shortland

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 6 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many nursing home beds are there in the electoral division of Shortland.
(2) How many of those nursing home beds are owned and operated by (a) private operators and companies and (b) community or religious organisations.
(3) How many nursing home beds are available at each location.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are 413 nursing home beds in the electoral division of Shortland.
(2) (a) 306 of those beds are owned and operated by private operators. Information as to whether private operators are also companies is not readily available.
(b) 60 beds are owned and operated by a religious organisation.
(c) The remaining 47 beds are owned and operated by the New South Wales State Government.
(3) The following illustrates the number of nursing home beds available at each location.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 13 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say which states are qualified to attend the 12th ILO Asian Regional Conference to be held in Bangkok from 9 to 11 December 1997.
(2) Is he also able to say which ILO freedom of association conventions have been ratified by those states.
(3) What preparations is Australia making to participate in the conference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) ILO Members in the Asian Region are qualified to attend, and we expect allwill be invited to participate in the Asian Regional Conference from 9-11 December 1997 in Bangkok. A list of Asian Region members appears in the answer to question 2.
(2) There are two major ILO freedom of association conventions:
No 87, Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948, and No 98, Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining, 1949.
Other freedom of association conventions include:
No 11, Right of Association (Agriculture), 1921 No 135, Workers' Representatives, 1971 No 141, Rural Workers' Organisations, 1975, and No 151, Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978.

The following list indicates, in respect of those Conventions, the ratification record of each ILO member State in the Asian Region, according to the ILO' s publication Lists of Ratifications by Convention and by country (as at 31 December 1995).

PARA.TAB: Syrian Arab Republic—C11, C87, C98, C135

ANSWER.PARA: (3) No decision has been taken in relation to Australian participation at the conference. The agenda for the Conference is expected to be adopt

ed at the March 1997 ILO Governing Body meeting. The Government will be in a position to consider Australia's participation, once the agenda is finalised and a formal invitation has been received from the ILO.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, upon notice on 13 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many consultancies valued at $5000 or more have been commissioned by the Minister's Department since 1 April 1996.
(2) Which firms were awarded individual consultancies.
(3) What was the (a) value and (b) broad nature of each consultancy.
(4) What was the duration of each consultancy which has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is provided in (Question No. 1315) which follows.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, upon notice on 13 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many consultancies valued at $5000 or more have been commissioned by the Minister's Department since 1 April 1996.
(2) Which firms were awarded individual consultancies.
(3) What was the (a) value and (b) broad nature of each consultancy.
(4) What was the duration of each consultancy which has been completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Foreign Affairs and Trade—118
AusAID—414
Austrade—56
(2) A listing of the firms is attached.
(3) (a) For the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AusAID a listing of the value of each consultancy is attached.

In relation to Austrade, the provision of Commercial‐In‐Confidence information other than to a Parliamentary Committee under privilege is in breach of the Austrade Act and therefore the values have been excluded.
(b) The broad nature of each consultancy is attached.
(4) The duration of each consultancy which has been completed is listed on the attached.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Constitutional Commission unanimously recommend the repeal of subsection 394(1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.
(2) Will he bring up-to-date his predecessor's answer to question No. 78 (Hansard , 27 September 1993, page 1153) concerning this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) On 10 May 1993, you asked the then Attorney-General, the Hon Michael Lavarch MP, upon notice, whether the Government had considered the Constitutional Commission's recommendation that subsection 394(1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be repealed. On 27 September 1993, Mr Lavarch answered this question by stating that he was advised by the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services that the answer was no. I am advised that there has been no consideration by the Government of the Constitutional Commission's recommendation since that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister undertaken ministerial travel overseas since 18 September 1996; if so (a) how many visits has the Minister undertaken, (b) what was the duration of each visit and (c) which countries were visited.
(2) What has been the cost of each overseas visit the Minister has undertaken since entering the Ministry.

(3) Has the Minister utilised frequent flyer points for overseas or internal flights on official business in accordance with the direction issued by the Minister for Administrative Services in April 1996; if so, to what extent were points used and on which overseas visits were they used; if not, why not and what action is being taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(b) (i) 5 days (22-26 November 1996); (ii) 3 days (15 to 17 February 1997).
(c) (i) Philippines; (ii) New Zealand.

(2) The following information has been supplied by the Department of Administrative Services as at 11 March 1997. However, it should be noted that all accounts pertaining to the visits may not yet be acquitted, particularly in relation to the Prime Minister's visit to New Zealand.

The figures provided by the Department of Administrative Services cover the cost of accommodation, meals, telephone and fax calls, airfares, passport costs, health vaccinations and trip associated medication, baggage insurance, car hire, ground transport, incidentals (tips and gratuities etc) and personal hospitality for the Prime Minister and the Prime Minister's personal staff.
(i) $141,701 (Marshall Islands); (ii) $195,481 (Indonesia and Japan); (iii) $336,483 (Philippines); (iv) $1,028 (New Zealand).
(3) No. Apart from the Indonesia/Japan visit, all domestic and international travel was undertaken by special purpose aircraft.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Industrial Relations: Overseas Travel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, on notice, on 3 March 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister undertaken ministerial travel overseas since 18 September 1996; if so (a) how many visits has the Minister undertaken, (b) what was the duration of each visit and (c) which countries were visited.
(2) What has been the cost of each overseas trip the Minister has undertaken since entering the Ministry.

(3) Has the Minister utilised frequent flyer points for overseas or internal flights on official business in accordance with the direction issued by the Minister for Administrative Services in April 1996; if so, to what extent were points used and on which overseas visit were they used; if not, why not and what action is being taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No
(2) Nil
(3) No. However, frequent flyer points will be used in respect of my forthcoming overseas visit.
